data.title: Not so Grimm: BBT’s new take on ‘Hansel + Gretel’

For information on submitting an obituary, please contact Reading Eagle by phone at 610-371-5018, or email at obituaries@readingeagle.com or fax at 610-371-5193.

Most obituaries published in the Reading Eagle are submitted through funeral homes and cremation services, but we will accept submissions from families. Obituaries can be emailed to obituaries@readingeagle.com.

In addition to the text of the obituary, any photographs that you wish to include can be attached to this email. Please put the text of the obituary in a Word document, a Google document or in the body of the email. The Reading Eagle also requires a way to verify the death, so please include either the phone number of the funeral home or cremation service that is in charge of the deceased's care or a photo of his/her death certificate. We also request that your full name, phone number and address are all included in this email.

All payments by families must be made with a credit card. We will send a proof of the completed obituary before we require payment. The obituary cannot run, however, until we receive payment in full.

Obituaries can be submitted for any future date, but they must be received no later than 3:00 p.m. the day prior to its running for it to be published.

Please call the obituary desk, at 610-371-5018, for information on pricing.

Berks Ballet Theatre will premiere a new ballet, “Hansel & Gretel,” choreographed and directed by BBT’s resident choreographer, Nathan Bland, Saturday at 2 p.m. in the Miller Center for the Arts.

Last May, the company allowed the audience to preview part of “Hansel and Gretel” during the company’s spring performance, titled “Fairy Tales.” Now the ballet is complete, and will star BBT members Amber Warchol as Gretel and Ahna Romanski as the Old Lady/Witch, with guest dancer Richy Romero of First State Ballet Theatre in Wilmington, Del., as Hansel.

Since the ballet is based on the well-known Brothers Grimm fairy tale, it will appeal to children, but the dancing will appeal to adults in the audience, who also will enjoy the music Bland has selected.

YOU MIGHT ALSO LIKE: Dance teacher wants people in the Berks area to find wellness through creative dance

The original story, like many traditional folk tales, is quite dark, especially in some versions, so Bland said he tried to retell it in a way that would not frighten children.

“I took out the part about the father dropping his children off in the forest and leaving them,” he said. “So they’re just wandering, lost in the forest, as the story begins.”

In earlier versions, including the opera by Engelbert Humperdinck, Hansel and Gretel’s stepmother convinces their father they don’t have enough food to feed the two children as well as themselves, so they should get rid of them by taking them into the forest and abandoning them.

Bland said the witch in the ballet (disguised at first as an old lady) is informed about Hansel and Gretel’s presence in the forest by four dancing birds (which will be portrayed by Jessica Bealer, Emily Brossman, Jaiden Harwell and Christina Kopecky), and she sends her attendants (Harwell and Katie Riddle) to find the children.

Hansel and Gretel, meanwhile, stumble upon some gumdrops that come to life (Riddle, Ellie Folga and Lorelei Obst), which terrifies them.

The rest of the story follows a familiar sequence, with the children enticed by the Gingerbread House. As they nibble on it, they’re caught by the witch, who is about to bake the children in the oven when Gretel throws her into the oven instead. The ballet ends with a celebration of the evil witch’s demise.

The addition of the extra characters, Bland said, provided more depth and interaction to the tale.

Bland said he chose an array of classical music to help tell the story, searching through many albums for pieces that would fit.

“I didn’t want to use music from the opera, or music people would know,” he said. “I found some unique, fun things.”

He selected works by the Czech composer Oskar Nedbal from his 1907 ballet “From Fairy Tale to Fairy Tale”; by Dmitri Shostakovich from his “Jazz Suite” of the 1930s; by Romanian Gypsy composer Georges Boulanger (1893-1958), a violinist/conductor/composer; and by Austrian violinist/composer Fritz Kreisler (1875-1962). There are also pieces recorded by contemporary American violinist Michaela Paetsch Neftel (born in 1961).

Bland said families can enjoy a pre-performance reception beginning at 12:30 p.m. in the upstairs lobby of the Miller Center, where members of the cast, in costume, will be available to meet children and supervise stories and crafts.

The reception also will offer treats from Ady Cakes and ice cream from Sweet Ride (both of West Reading), as well as a candy “bar.”

Contact Susan L. Pena: weekend@readingeagle.com.

Originally Published: May 2, 2019 at 1:00 a.m.
